{{featured article}} {{Use American English|date=August 2013}}{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox Constellation |name = Perseus |abbreviation = Per |genitive = Persei |pronounce = {{IPAc-en|ˈ|p|ɜr|s|iː|ə|s}} or {{IPAc-en|ˈ|p|ɜr|s|juː|s}};
genitive {{IPAc-en|ˈ|p|ɜr|s|iː|.|aɪ}} |symbolism = [[Perseus]] |RA = 3 |dec= +45 |family = [[Perseus Family|Perseus]] |quadrant = NQ1 |areatotal = 615 |arearank = 24th |numbermainstars = 19 |numberbfstars = 65 |numberstarsplanets = 7 |numberbrightstars = 5 |numbernearbystars = 0 |brighteststarname = [[Alpha Persei|α Per]] (Mirfak) |starmagnitude = 1.79 |neareststarname = G 174-14 |stardistancely = 33.62 |stardistancepc = 10.31 |numbermessierobjects = 2 |meteorshowers = [[Perseids]]
[[September Perseids]] |bordering = [[Aries (constellation)|Aries]]
[[Taurus (constellation)|Taurus]]
[[Auriga (constellation)|Auriga]]
[[Camelopardalis]]
[[Cassiopeia (constellation)|Cassiopeia]]
[[Andromeda (constellation)|Andromeda]]
[[Triangulum]] |latmax = [[North Pole|90]] |latmin = [[35th parallel south|35]] |month = December |notes= }} '''Perseus''', named after the [[Greek mythology|Greek mythological]] hero [[Perseus]], is a [[constellation]] in the [[northern sky]]. It was one of 48 listed by the 2nd-century astronomer [[Ptolemy]] and among the [[88 modern constellations]] defined by the [[International Astronomical Union]] (IAU). It is located in the [[Celestial sphere|northern celestial hemisphere]] near several other constellations named after legends surrounding Perseus, including [[Andromeda (constellation)|Andromeda]] to the west and [[Cassiopeia (constellation)|Cassiopeia]] to the north. Perseus is also bordered by [[Aries (constellation)|Aries]] and [[Taurus (constellation)|Taurus]] to the south, [[Auriga (constellation)|Auriga]] to the east, [[Camelopardalis]] to the north, and [[Triangulum]] to the west. The [[galactic plane]] of the [[Milky Way]] passes through Perseus but is mostly obscured by [[molecular cloud]]s. The constellation's brightest star is the yellow-white [[supergiant]] [[Alpha Persei]] (also called Mirfak), which shines at [[apparent magnitude|magnitude]] 1.79. It and many of the surrounding stars are members of an [[open cluster]] known as the [[Alpha Persei Cluster]]. The best-known star, however, is [[Algol]] (Beta Persei), linked with ominous legends because of its [[variable star|variability]], which is noticeable to the naked eye. Rather than being an intrinsically variable star, it is an [[eclipsing binary]]. Other notable star systems in Perseus include [[X Persei]], a binary system containing a [[neutron star]], and [[GK Persei]], a [[nova]] that peaked at magnitude 0.2 in 1901. The [[Double Cluster]], comprising two open clusters quite near each other in the sky, was known to the ancient Chinese. The constellation gives its name to the [[Perseus Cluster]] (Abell 426), a massive galaxy cluster located 250 million [[light-year]]s from Earth. It hosts the [[radiant (meteor shower)|radiant]] of the annual [[Perseids]] [[meteor shower]]—one of the most prominent meteor showers in the sky. ==History and mythology== {{See also|Perseus}} [[File:Sidney Hall - Urania's Mirror - Perseus.jpg|thumb|left|300px|alt=Constellation drawing of Perseus |Perseus carrying the head of Medusa the Gorgon, as depicted in ''[[Urania's Mirror]]'', a set of constellation cards published in London c.1825{{cite web|url=http://www.ianridpath.com/atlases/urania.htm |first=I. |last=Ridpath |title=Urania's Mirror c.1825 – Ian Ridpath's Old Star Atlases |accessdate=17 July 2013}}]] The constellation of Perseus may be derived from the Babylonian Old Man (MUL.SHU.GI) constellation, then associated with East in the [[MUL.APIN]]{{mdash}}an astronomical compilation dating to around 1000 BCE.{{cite book|last=Dalley|first=S.|title=The Legacy of Mesopotamia|year=1998|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford, United Kingdom|isbn=978-0-19-814946-0|page=128}} In Greek mythology, Perseus was the son of [[Danaë]], who was sent by King [[Polydectes]] to bring the head of [[Medusa]] the [[Gorgon]]{{mdash}}whose visage caused all who gazed upon her to turn to stone{{mdash}}as a wedding gift. Perseus slew Medusa in her sleep, and [[Pegasus]] and [[Chrysaor]] appeared from her body.{{cite web|url=http://www.ianridpath.com/startales/perseus.htm |first=I. |last=Ridpath |title=Star Tales – Perseus|accessdate=28 July 2013}} Perseus continued to the realm of [[Cepheus, King of Aethiopia|Cepheus]] whose daughter [[Andromeda (mythology)|Andromeda]] was to be sacrificed to [[Cetus (mythology)|Cetus]] the sea monster. Perseus rescued the princess Andromeda from Cetus by turning it to stone with Medusa's head.{{cite web|url=http://www.ianridpath.com/startales/andromeda.htm |first=I. |last=Ridpath |title=Star Tales – Andromeda|accessdate=28 July 2013}} He turned Polydectes and his followers to stone and appointed [[Dictys|Dictys the fisherman]] king. Perseus and Andromeda married and had six children. In the sky, Perseus lies near the constellations Andromeda, Cepheus, [[Cassiopeia (mythology)|Cassiopeia]] (Andromeda's mother), Cetus, and Pegasus. ===In non-Western astronomy=== {{See also|Chinese astronomy}} Four [[Chinese constellations]] are contained in the area of the sky identified with Perseus in the West. ''Tiānchuán'' (天船), the Celestial Boat, was the third [[paranatellon]] (small [[Asterism (astronomy)|asterism]] of stars) of the third house of the [[White Tiger of the West]], representing the boats that Chinese people were reminded to build in case of a catastrophic flood season. Incorporating stars from the northern part of the constellation, it contained Mu, Delta, Psi, Alpha, Gamma and Eta Persei.Schlegel, p. 346. ''Jīshuǐ'' (積水), the Swollen Waters, was the fourth paranatellon of the aforementioned house, representing the potential of unusually high floods during the end of August and beginning of September at the beginning of the flood season. Lambda and possibly Mu Persei lay within it.Schlegel, p. 349. ''Dàlíng'' (大陵), the Great Trench, was the fifth paranatellon of that house, representing the trenches where criminals executed en masse in August were interred. It was formed by Kappa, Omega, Rho, 24, 17 and 15 Persei. The pile of corpses prior to their internment was represented by ''Jīshī'' (積屍, Algol), the sixth paranatellon of the house. The [[Double Cluster]], h and Chi Persei, had special significance in [[Chinese astronomy]]. Known as Hsi and Ho, the two clusters represented two astronomers who failed to predict a [[total solar eclipse]] and were subsequently beheaded.Staal, 1984, p. 161. In Polynesia, Perseus was not commonly recognized as a separate constellation; the only people that named it were those of the [[Society Islands]], who called it ''Faa-iti'', meaning "Little Valley".Makemson, 1941, p. 203 Algol may have been named ''Matohi'' by the [[Māori people]], but the evidence for this identification is disputed. ''Matohi'' ("Split") occasionally came into conflict with ''Tangaroa-whakapau'' over which of them should appear in the sky, the outcome affecting the tides. It matches the Maori description of a blue-white star near [[Aldebaran]] but does not disappear as the myth would indicate.Makemson, 1941, pp. 233–234 == Characteristics == Perseus is bordered by [[Aries (constellation)|Aries]] and [[Taurus (constellation)|Taurus]] to the south, [[Auriga (constellation)|Auriga]] to the east, [[Camelopardalis]] and [[Cassiopeia (constellation)|Cassiopea]] to the north, and [[Andromeda (constellation)|Andromeda]] and [[Triangulum]] to the west. Covering 615 [[square degree]]s, it ranks twenty-fourth of the 88 constellations in size. It appears prominently in the northern sky during the Northern Hemisphere's spring. Its main [[asterism (astronomy)|asterism]] consists of 19 stars. The constellation's boundaries, as set by [[Eugène Joseph Delporte|Eugène Delporte]] in 1930, are defined by a 26-sided polygon. In the [[equatorial coordinate system]], the [[right ascension]] coordinates of these borders lie between {{RA|01|29.1}} and {{RA|04|51.2}}, while the [[declination]] coordinates are between {{dec|30.92}} and {{dec|59.11}}.{{cite journal | title=Perseus, Constellation Boundary | work=The Constellations | publisher=International Astronomical Union | url=http://www.iau.org/public/constellations/#per | accessdate=16 February 2013}} The [[International Astronomical Union]] (IAU) adopted the three-letter abbreviation "Per" for the constellation in 1922.{{cite journal | last=Russell | first=H. N. | title=The New International Symbols for the Constellations | journal=Popular Astronomy | volume=30 | pages=469–71 |bibcode=1922PA.....30..469R | year=1922}} ==Notable features== [[Image:PerseusCC.jpg|thumb|right|200px|alt=Night sky photograph of the constellation Perseus |The constellation Perseus as it can be seen by the naked eye]] ===Stars=== {{see also|List of stars in Perseus}} [[Algol]] (from the Arabic '''رأس الغول''' ''Ra's al-Ghul'', which means ''The Demon's Head''), also known by its [[Bayer designation]] Beta Persei, is the best-known star in Perseus. Representing the eye of the Gorgon Medusa in Greek mythology, it was called ''Rosh ha Satan'' ("[[Satan]]'s Head") in Hebrew. Located 92.8 [[light-year]]s from Earth, it varies in [[apparent magnitude]] from a minimum of 3.5 to a maximum of 2.3 over a period of 2.867 days.{{Cite book |title = Deep Sky Objects |last = Levy |first = D. H. |publisher = Prometheus Books|year = 2005 |isbn = 1-59102-361-0 |pages=60–61}} The star system is the prototype of a group of [[Eclipsing binary|eclipsing binary stars]] named [[Algol variable]]s, though it has a third member to make up what is actually a [[triple star]] system.{{cite web |url=http://stars.astro.illinois.edu/sow/algol.html |title=Algol |last=Kaler |first=Jim |authorlink=Jim Kaler |work=Stars |publisher=University of Illinois |accessdate=25 November 2013}} The brightest component is a [[B-type main sequence star|blue-white main sequence star]] of [[Stellar classification|spectral type]] B8V,{{cite web |url =http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=bet+Per |title = * Beta Persei – Eclipsing Binary of Algol Type (Detached) |publisher = [[SIMBAD]] | accessdate = 18 February 2013}} which is 3.5 times as massive and 180 times as luminous as the [[Sun]]. The secondary component is an orange subgiant star of type K0IV that has begun cooling and expanding to 3.5 times the radius of the Sun,{{cite web |url =http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=NAME+ALGOL+B |title = Algol B – Star in Double System |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 18 February 2013}} and has 4.5 times the luminosity and 80% of its mass. These two are separated by only 0.05 [[astronomical units]] (AU)—five percent of the distance between the Earth and Sun; the main dip in brightness arises when the larger fainter companion passes in front of the hotter brighter primary. The tertiary component is a main sequence star of type A7,{{cite web |url =http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=NAME+ALGOL+C |title = Algol C – Star in Double System |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 18 February 2013}} which is located on average 2.69 AU from the other two stars. [[AG Persei]] is another Algol variable in Perseus, whose primary component is a B-type main sequence star with an apparent magnitude of 6.69.{{cite web |url =http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=AG+Per |title = * AG Persei – Eclipsing Binary of Algol Type (Detached) |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 15 February 2013}} [[Phi Persei]] is a double star, although the two components do not eclipse each other. The primary star is a [[Be star]] of spectral type B0.5, possibly a giant star, and the secondary companion is likely a stellar remnant. The secondary has a similar spectral type to O-type [[subdwarf]]s.{{cite journal |last1=Thaller |first1=M. L. |last2=Bagnuolo |first2=W. G. |last3=Gies|first3=D. R. |last4=Penny |first4=L. R. |title=Tomographic Separation of Composite Spectra. III. Ultraviolet Detection of the Hot Companion of phi Persei |journal=Astrophysical Journal |volume=448 |pages=878–84|bibcode=1995ApJ...448..878T |url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/full/1995ApJ...448..878T|doi = 10.1086/176016 |year=1995 }} With the historical name Mirfak (Arabic for ''elbow'') or Algenib, [[Alpha Persei]] is the brightest star of this constellation with an apparent magnitude of 1.79. A [[supergiant]] of spectral type F5Ib located around 590 light-years away from Earth,{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=alf+Per |title = V* Alpha Persei – Variable Star |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 31 January 2013}} Mirfak has 5,000 times the [[luminosity]] and 42 times the diameter of our Sun. It is the brightest member of the [[Alpha Persei Cluster]] (also known as ''[[Melotte Catalogue|Melotte]] 20'' and ''[[Collinder catalog|Collinder]] 39''), which is an [[open cluster]] containing many luminous stars. Neighboring bright stars that are members include the Be stars [[Delta Persei|Delta]] (magnitude 3.0),{{cite web |url =http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=del+Per |title = * Delta Persei – Be Star |publisher = SIMBAD |accessdate = 31 January 2013}} [[Psi Persei|Psi]] (4.3),{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=psi+Per |title = * Psi Persei – Be Star |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 31 January 2013}} and [[48 Persei]] (4.0);{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=48+Per |title = * c Persei – Be star |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 31 January 2013}} the [[Beta Cephei variable]] [[Epsilon Persei]] (2.9);{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=eps+Per |title = V* Epsilon Persei – Variable Star of Beta Cep Type |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 31 January 2013}} and the stars [[29 Persei|29]] (5.2),{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=29+Per |title = * 29 Per – Star |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 31 January 2013}} [[30 Persei|30]] (5.5),{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=30+Per |title = * 30 Persei – Star |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 31 January 2013}} [[31 Persei|31]] (5.0),{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=31+Per|title = * 31 Persei – Star |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 28 December 2013}} and [[34 Persei]] (4.7).{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=34+Per |title = * 34 Persei – Star |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 31 January 2013}} Of magnitude 4.05, nearby [[Iota Persei]] has been considered a member of the group, but is actually located a mere 34 light-years distant. This star is very similar to our Sun, shining with 2.2 times its luminosity. It is a yellow main sequence star of spectral type G0V. Extensive searches have failed to find evidence of it having a planetary system.{{cite web|url=http://stars.astro.illinois.edu/sow/iotaper.html |title=Iota Persei|last=Kaler|first=J. B.|work=Stars|publisher=University of Illinois|accessdate=5 November 2013}} Named Atik, [[Zeta Persei]] is the third-brightest star in the constellation at magnitude 2.86. Around 750 light-years from Earth, it is a blue-white supergiant 26–27 times the radius of the Sun and 47,000 times its luminosity. It is the brightest star (as seen from Earth) of a [[moving group]] of bright blue-white giant and supergiant stars, the Perseus OB2 Association or Zeta Persei Association. Zeta is a triple star system, with a companion blue-white main sequence star of spectral type B8 and apparent magnitude 9.16 around 3900 AU distant from the primary, and a white main sequence star of magnitude 9.90 and spectral type A2, some 50,000 AU away, that may or may not be gravitationally bound to the other two.{{cite web|url=http://stars.astro.illinois.edu/sow/zetaper.html |title=Zeta Persei|last=Kaler|first=J. B.|work=Stars|publisher=University of Illinois|accessdate=5 November 2013}} [[X Persei]] is a double system in this association; one component is a hot, bright star and the other is a [[neutron star]].{{cite doi|10.1086/318236}} With an apparent magnitude of 6.72, it is too dim to be seen with the naked eye even in perfectly dark conditions.{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=X+Per|title = V* X Persei – High Mass X-ray Binary |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 8 February 2013}} The system is an [[X-ray]] source and the primary star appears to be undergoing substantial mass loss.{{cite journal|last1 = White |first1 = N. E. |last2 = Swank |first2 = J. H. |last3 = Holt |first3 = S. S. |last4 = Parmar|first4 = A. N. |title = A Comparison of the X-ray Properties of X Persei and Gamma Cassiopeiae |volume = 263 |issue = 1 |pages = 277–88 |year = 1982 |journal = Astrophysical Journal|doi = 10.1086/160502|bibcode = 1982ApJ...263..277W }} Once thought to be a member of the Perseus OB2 Association,{{cite journal | last1=Steenbrugge | first1=K. C. | last2=De Bruijne | first2=J. H. J. |last3=Hoogerwerf | first3=R. | last4=De Zeeuw | first4=P. T. | title=Radial Velocities of Early-Type Stars in the Perseus OB2 Association | journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics | volume=402 | pages=587–605 | year=2003 | doi=10.1051/0004-6361:20030277 |arxiv = astro-ph/0302428 | issue=2 |bibcode = 2003A&A...402..587S }} [[Omicron Persei]] is a multiple star system with a combined visual magnitude of 3.85.{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=omicron+persei|title = V* Omicron Persei – Ellipsoidal Variable Star |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 17 February 2013}} It is composed of two blue-white stars{{mdash}}a giant of spectral class B1.5 and main sequence star of B3{{mdash}}which orbit each other every 4.5 days and are distorted into ovoids due to their small separation. The system has a third star about which little is known. At an estimated distance of 1475 light-years from Earth, the system is now thought to lie too far from the center of the Zeta Persei group to belong to it.{{cite web|url=http://stars.astro.illinois.edu/sow/atik.html|title=Atik (Omicron Persei)|last=Kaler|first=J. B.|work=Stars|publisher=University of Illinois|accessdate=16 February 2013}} [[GRO J0422+32]] (V518 Persei) is another X-ray binary in Perseus. One component is a [[red dwarf]] star of spectral type M4.5V,{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=GRO+J0422%2B32&NbIdent=1&Radius=2&Radius.unit=arcmin&submit=submit+id |title = V* V518 Persei – Low Mass X-ray Binary |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 10 December 2013}} which orbits a mysterious dense and heavy object—possibly a [[black hole]]—every 5.1 hours.{{cite journal|last=Paredes |year=2012|title=Nonthermal Processes and Neutrino Emission from the Black Hole GRO J0422+32 in a Bursting State|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|volume=546|issue=A46|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2012/10/aa19961-12.pdf|bibcode=2012A&A...546A..46V|first=Y.|pages=46|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201219961|first2=Y.|first3=G. E.|first4=J. M.}} The system is an X-ray nova, meaning that it experiences periodic outbursts in the X-ray band of the [[electromagnetic spectrum]].{{cite journal|displayauthors=6 |last1 = Callanan |first1 = P. J. |last2 = Garcia |first2 = M. R. |last3 = McClintock |first3 = J. E. |last4 = Zhao |first4 = P. |last5 = Remillard |first5 = R. A. |last6 = Bailyn |first6 = C. D.|title = Observations of the X-ray Nova GRO J0422+32. 1: Outburst and the decay to quiescence |journal = Astrophysical Journal |volume = 442 |issue = 2 |pages = 786–99 |last7 = Orosz|first7 = J. A.|last8 = Harmon|first8 = B. A. |last9 = Paciesas|first9 = W. S.|year = 1995|doi = 10.1086/175402|bibcode = 1995ApJ...441..786C }} If the system does indeed contain a black hole, it would be the smallest one ever recorded.{{cite doi|10.1086/379311}} Further analysis in 2012 calculated a mass of 2.1 solar masses, which raises questions as to what the object actually is as it appears to be too small to be a black hole.{{cite journal|last=Kalogera|first=Laura|coauthors=Bailyn, Charles D.; Farr, Will M.; Kalogera, Vicky |year=2012|title=Mass Measurements of Black Holes in X-ray Transients: is There a Mass Gap? |journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=757|issue=36|pages=17pp.|url=http://iopscience.iop.org/0004-637X/757/1/36/pdf/apj_757_1_36.pdf|bibcode=2012ApJ...757...36K|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/757/1/36}} [[GK Persei]], also known as Nova Persei 1901, is a bright nova that appeared halfway between Algol and Delta Persei. Discovered on February 21, 1901 by Scottish amateur astronomer [[Thomas David Anderson]], it peaked at magnitude 0.2{{mdash}}almost as bright as [[Capella (star)|Capella]] and [[Vega]]. It faded to [[Apparent magnitude#Table of notable celestial objects|magnitude 13]] around 30 years after its peak brightness.Mots & Nathanson, 1991, p. 342 [[Xi Persei]], traditionally known as Menkhib,{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=Xi+Per|title = NAME Menkhib – Star |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 16 February 2013}} a blue giant of spectral type O7III, is one of the hottest bright stars in the sky,{{cite doi|10.1051/0004-6361:20034594}} with a surface temperature of 37,500 K. It is one of the more massive stars, being between 26 and 32 solar masses,{{cite arXiv|eprint=1005.0258v2|last1=Krtička|last2=Kubát|first2=J. |title=CMF Models of Hot Star Winds I. Test of the Sobolev Approximation in the Case of Pure Line Transitions|class=astro-ph.SR|year=2010|first1=J.|author2=Jiri Kubat}} and is 330,000 times as luminous as our Sun.{{cite web|url=http://stars.astro.illinois.edu/sow/menkib.html |title=Menkib |last=Kaler|first=J. B.|work=Stars|publisher=University of Illinois|accessdate=5 November 2013}} Named Gorgonea Tertia, [[Rho Persei]] varies in brightness like Algol, but is a pulsating rather than eclipsing star. At an advanced stage of stellar evolution, it is a red giant that has expanded for the second time to have a radius around 150 times that of our Sun. Its helium has been fused into heavier elements and its core is composed of carbon and oxygen.{{cite web|url=http://stars.astro.illinois.edu/sow/gorgtert.html |title=Gorgonea Tertia |last=Kaler|first=J. B.|work=Stars|publisher=University of Illinois|accessdate=5 November 2013}} It is a [[semiregular variable star]] of the [[Mu Cephei]] type, whose [[apparent magnitude]] varies between 3.3 and 4.0{{Cite journal | display-authors=1 | last1=Kukarkin | first1=B. V. | last2=Kholopov | first2=P. N. | last3=Pskovsky | first3=Y. P. | last4=Efremov | first4=Y. N. | last5=Kukarkina | first5=N. P. | last6=Kurochkin | first6=N. E. | last7=Medvedeva | first7=G. I. | contribution=The third edition containing information on 20437 variable stars discovered and designated till 1968 | title=General Catalogue of Variable Stars | edition=3rd | year=1971 | bibcode=1971GCVS3.C......0K | pages=0 | journal=General Catalogue of Variable Stars | postscript={{inconsistent citations}} }} with periods of 50, 120 and 250 days.{{Cite journal | last1=Yeşilyaprak | first1=C. | last2=Aslan | first2=Z. | title=Period-luminosity Relation for M-type Semiregular Variables from Hipparcos Parallaxes | journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] | volume=355 | issue=2 | pages=601–07 |date=December 2004 | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2004.08344.x | bibcode=2004MNRAS.355..601Y | postscript={{inconsistent citations}} }} The Double Cluster contains three even larger stars, each over 700 [[solar radius|solar radii]]:{{cite journal |title=The Effective Temperature Scale of Galactic Red Supergiants: Cool, but Not As Cool As We Thought |first1=E. M. |last1=Levesque |first2=P. |last2=Massey |first3=K. A. G. |last3=Olsen |first4=B. |last4=Plez |first5=E. |last5=Josselin |first6=A. |last6=Maeder |first7=G. |last7=Meynet |journal=The Astrophysical Journal |volume=628 |issue=2 |year=2005 |pages=973–85 |doi=10.1086/430901|arxiv = astro-ph/0504337 |bibcode = 2005ApJ...628..973L }} [[S Persei|S]], [[RS Persei|RS]], and [[SU Persei]] are all semiregular pulsating [[Red supergiant|M-type supergiants]].{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=S+Per|title = V* S Persei – Semi-Regular Pulsating Star |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 13 February 2013}}{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=S+Per|title = V* RS Persei – Semi-Regular Pulsating Star |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 13 February 2013}}{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=S+Per|title = V* SU Persei – Semi-Regular Pulsating Star |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 13 February 2013}} The stars are not visible to the naked eye; SU Persei, the brightest of the three, has an apparent magnitude of 7.9 and thus is visible through binoculars. [[AX Persei]] is another binary star, the primary component is a [[red giant]] in an advanced phase of [[stellar evolution]], which is transferring material onto an [[accretion disc]] around a smaller star. The star system is one of the few eclipsing [[symbiotic binary|symbiotic binaries]], but is unusual because the secondary star is not a white dwarf, but an [[A-type star]].{{cite web |url =http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=AX+Per|title = V* AX Persei – Symbiotic Star |publisher = SIMBAD| accessdate = 15 February 2013}}{{cite journal |last1 = Mikołajewska |first1=J.|last2 = Kenyon |first2 = S. J. |title = On the Nature of the Symbiotic Binary AX Persei |year = 1992 |pages = 579–92 |volume = 103 |issue = 2 |publisher = Astronomical Journal|url=http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/full/1992AJ....103..579M |doi=10.1086/116085|bibcode = 1992AJ....103..579M |journal = The Astronomical Journal }} [[DY Persei]] is a variable star that is the prototype of [[DY Persei variable]]s, which are carbon-rich [[R Coronae Borealis variable]]s that exhibit the variability of [[asymptotic giant branch]] stars.{{cite doi|10.1086/321369}} DY Persei itself is a [[carbon star]] that is too dim to see through binoculars, with an apparent magnitude of 10.6.{{cite web |url =http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=DY+Per|title = V* DY Persei – Semi-Regular Pulsating Star |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 14 February 2013}} Seven stars in Perseus have been found to have planetary systems. [[V718 Persei]] is a star in the young open cluster [[IC 348]] that appears to be periodically eclipsed by a giant planet every 4.7 years.{{cite doi|10.1051/0004-6361:200810349}} This has been inferred to be an object with a maximum mass of 6 times that of [[Jupiter]] and an orbital radius of 3.3 AU.{{cite journal| last1=Herbst | first1=W. | last2=Yau | first2=A. | last3=Semkov | first3=E. | title=The Light Curve of V713 Per (HMW 15): Evidence for Gravitational Sculpting by an Object Embedded in the Circumstellar Disk|journal=American Astronomical Society| volume=42 |page=335 |year=2010| bibcode=2010AAS...21542931H}} ===Deep-sky objects=== [[File:NGC869NGC884.jpg|thumb|left|300px|alt=Photograph of The Double Cluster |The Double Cluster (NGC 869 and NGC 884)]] The [[galactic plane]] of the [[Milky Way]] passes through Perseus, but is much less obvious than elsewhere in the sky as it is mostly obscured by [[molecular cloud]]s.{{cite book|author=Crossen, Craig; Rhemann, Gerald|title=Sky Vistas: Astronomy for Binoculars and Richest-Field Telescopes|publisher=Springer|location=New York, New York|year=2004|page=177|isbn=3-211-00851-9|url=http://books.google.com/?id=mfJeWrJRqrkC&pg=PA177&dq=perseus+milky+way#v=onepage&q=perseus%20milky%20way&f=false}} The [[Perseus Arm]] is a spiral arm of the Milky Way galaxy and stretches across the sky from the constellation [[Cassiopeia (constellation)|Cassiopeia]] through Perseus and [[Auriga (constellation)|Auriga]] to [[Gemini (constellation)|Gemini]] and [[Monoceros]].{{cite book|last=Ridpath|first=Ian|title=A Dictionary of Astronomy|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford, United Kingdom |year=2012|page=355|isbn=0-19-960905-5|url=http://books.google.com/?id=O31j9UJ3U4oC&pg=PA355&dq=%22perseus+arm%22#v=onepage&q=%22perseus%20arm%22&f=false}} This segment is towards the rim of the galaxy. Within the Perseus Arm lie two open clusters ([[NGC 869]] and [[NGC 884]]) known as the Double Cluster.{{cite book|last=De Laet|first=Rony |title=The Casual Sky Observer's Guide: Stargazing with Binoculars and Small Telescopes |publisher=Springer|location=New York, New York|year=2011|page=244|isbn=1-4614-0595-5|url=http://books.google.com/?id=3fhBelJk-30C&pg=PA244&dq=%22perseus+arm%22#v=onepage&q=%22perseus%20arm%22&f=false}} Sometimes known as h and Chi (χ) Persei respectively, they are easily visible through binoculars and small telescopes.{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=NGC+869|title = NGC 869 – Open (Galactic) Cluster |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 17 July 2013}}{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=NGC+884|title = NGC 884 – Open (Galactic) Cluster |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 17 July 2013}} Both lie more than 7,000 light-years from Earth and are several hundred light-years apart. The Double Cluster was first recorded during the reign of the Chinese king [[Tsung-K'ang]], who reigned during the [[Hsia Dynasty]] (2858–2146 BCE). Both clusters are of approximately magnitude 4 and 0.5 degrees in diameter. The two are [[Trumpler class]] I 3 r clusters, though NGC 869 is a [[Shapley–Sawyer Concentration Class|Shapley class]] f and NGC 884 is a Shapley class e cluster. These classifications indicate that they are both quite rich (dense); NGC 869 is the richer of the pair.{{cite doi|10.1086/341865}} The clusters are both distinct from the surrounding star field and are clearly concentrated at their centers. The constituent stars, numbering over 100 in each cluster, range widely in brightness.Levy, 2005, p. 86 [[Messier 34|M34]] is an open cluster that appears at magnitude 5.5,{{cite book | first=K. G. | last=Jones | year=1991 | edition=2nd | title=Messier's Nebulae and Star Clusters | work=The Practical Astronomy Handbook, Volume 2 | page=139 | publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|location=Cambridge, United Kingdom | isbn=0-521-37079-5 }} and is approximately 1,500 light-years from Earth.{{cite doi|10.1086/117865}} It contains about 100 stars scattered over a field of view larger than that of the full moon. M34 can be resolved with good eyesight but is best viewed using a telescope at low magnifications. IC 348 is a somewhat young open cluster that is still contained within the nebula from which its stars formed. It is located about 1,027 light-years from Earth, is about 2 million years old,{{cite doi|10.1086/376594}} and contains many stars with [[circumstellar disk]]s.{{cite doi|10.1086/499808}} Many [[brown dwarf]]s have been discovered in this cluster due to its age; since brown dwarfs cool as they age, it is easier to find them in younger clusters.{{cite news | title=Astronomers Discover Youngest and Lowest Mass Dwarfs in Solar Neighborhood | work=Science Daily | date=24 April 2009 |url=http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2009/04/090422085801.htm | accessdate=17 February 2013 }} There are many nebulae in Perseus. [[Little Dumbbell Nebula|M76]] is a [[planetary nebula]], also called the Little Dumbbell Nebula.{{cite doi|10.1888/0333750888/5314}} It appears two [[arc-minute]]s by one arc-minute across and has an apparent brightness of magnitude 10.1. [[California Nebula|NGC 1499]], also known as the California Nebula, is an [[emission nebula]] that was discovered in 1884–85 by American astronomer [[Edward Emerson Barnard|Edward E. Barnard]].{{cite web |url =http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=NGC+1499 |title = NGC 1499 – HII (Ionized) region |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 19 May 2013}} It is very difficult to observe visually because its low surface brightness makes it appear dimmer than most other emission nebulae.{{cite journal|last1 = Barnard |first1 = E. E. |title = Photograph of the Nebula NGC 1499 Near the Star Ksi Persei |journal = Astrophysical Journal |volume = 2 |page = 350 |year = 1895 |doi = 10.1086/140157|bibcode = 1895ApJ.....2..350B }} [[NGC 1333]] is a [[reflection nebula]] and a [[star forming region]].{{cite web |url =http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=NGC+1333 |title = NGC 1333 – Reflection Nebula |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 19 May 2013}}{{cite doi|10.1086/318060}} Perseus also contains a [[giant molecular cloud]], called the [[Perseus molecular cloud]]; it belongs to the [[Orion Arm|Orion Spur]] and is known for its low rate of star formation compared to similar clouds.{{cite doi|10.1086/510150}} Perseus contains some notable galaxies. [[NGC 1023]] is a [[barred spiral galaxy]] of magnitude 10.35, around 11.6 million pc (38 million ly) from Earth.{{cite web |title=NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database |publisher=Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology |work=Results for NGC 1023 |url=http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?objname=NGC+1023&img_stamp=yes&extend=no |accessdate=30 March 2013}} It is the principal member of the [[NGC 1023 group]] of galaxies and is possibly interacting with another galaxy.{{cite web |url =http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=NGC+1023 |title = NGC 1023 – Interacting galaxies |publisher = SIMBAD | accessdate = 30 March 2013}} [[NGC 1260]] is either a [[Lenticular galaxy|lenticular]] or tightly-wound [[spiral galaxy]] about 76.7 million pc (250 million ly) from Earth. It was the host galaxy of the supernova [[SN 2006gy]], one of the brightest ever recorded. It is a member of the [[Perseus Cluster]] (Abell 426),{{cite journal|last=Ofek, E. O.; Cameron, P. B.; Kasliwal, M. M.; Gal-Yam, A.; Rau, A.; Kulkarni, S. R.; Frail, D. A.; Chandra, P.; Cenko, S. B.; Soderberg, A. M.; Immler, S. |date=2007|title=SN 2006gy: An Extremely Luminous Supernova in the Galaxy NGC 1260|journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters|volume=659|issue=1|pages=L13-L16|url=http://iopscience.iop.org/1538-4357/659/1/L13/fulltext/|doi=10.1086/516749}} a massive [[galaxy cluster]] located 76.6 million pc (250 million ly) from Earth. With a [[redshift]] of 0.0179, Abell 426 is the closest major cluster to the Earth.{{cite web |title=NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database |publisher=Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology |work=Results for Perseus+CLUSTER |url=http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?objname=Perseus+CLUSTER&img_stamp=yes&extend=no |accessdate=19 May 2013}} [[NGC 1275]], a component of the cluster, is a [[Seyfert galaxy]] containing an [[active galactic nucleus|active nucleus]] that produces jets of material, surrounding the galaxy with massive bubbles. These bubbles create sound waves that travel through the Perseus Cluster, sounding a [[B♭ (musical note)|B flat]] 57 [[octaves]] below [[middle C]].{{cite web |title = Interpreting the 'Song' of a Distant Black Hole |last1=Jennar |first1=L. |last2=Dunbar |first2 = B. |publisher = [[NASA]] |year = 2008 |url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/goddard/universe/black_hole_sound.html |accessdate=10 August 2013}} This galaxy is a [[cD galaxy]] that has undergone many [[galactic merger]]s throughout its existence, as evidenced by the "high velocity system"{{mdash}}the remnants of a smaller galaxy{{mdash}}surrounding it. Its active nucleus is a strong source of radio waves. ===Meteor showers=== The [[Perseids]] are a prominent annual [[meteor shower]] that appear to radiate from Perseus from mid-July, peaking in activity between August 9 and 14 each year. Associated with [[Comet Swift–Tuttle]], they have been observed for about 2,000 years.{{cite web|url=http://meteorshowersonline.com/perseids.html |title=Observing the Perseids |publisher=Meteor Showers Online |last1=Kronk |first1=G. W |authorlink=Gary W. Kronk |accessdate=12 August 2009}} The [[September Epsilon Perseids]], discovered in 2012, are a meteor shower with an unknown parent body in the [[Oort cloud]].{{cite journal |journal = Sky & Telescope |year = 2012 |last = Jenniskens |first = P. |page = 22 |title = Mapping Meteoroid Orbits: New Meteor Showers Discovered}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ===Cited texts=== * {{Cite book | title = Deep Sky Objects | last = Levy | first = David H. | publisher = Prometheus Books | location = Amherst, New York | year = 2005 | isbn = 1-59102-361-0 }} * {{Cite journal | title = The Morning Star Rises: An Account of Polynesian Astronomy | last = Makemson | first = M. W. | year = 1941 | publisher = Yale University Press | location = New Haven, Connecticut }} * {{Cite book | last1 = Motz | first1 = L. | last2 = Nathanson | first2 = C. | year = 1991 | title = The Constellations: An Enthusiast's Guide to the Night Sky | publisher = Aurum Press | location = London, United Kingdom | isbn = 978-1-85410-088-7 }} * {{Cite book | title = Uranographie Chinoise | last = Schlegel | first = Gustaaf | publisher = Ch'eng Wen Publishing Company | location = Taipei, Republic of China | year = 1967 | origyear = 1875 | isbn = | language = French }} * {{Cite book | title = Stars of Jade: Astronomy and Star Lore of Very Ancient Imperial China | last = Staal | first = Julius D. W. | publisher = Writ Press |location = Decatur, Georgia | year = 1984 | isbn = 0-914653-00-8 }} ==External links== {{Commons and category|Perseus (constellation)}} * [http://www.allthesky.com/constellations/perseus/ The Deep Photographic Guide to the Constellations: Perseus] * [http://astrojan.zz.mu/perseus.htm The clickable Perseus] {{Stars of Perseus}} {{navconstel}} {{Sky|03|00|00|+|45|00|00|10}} [[Category:Perseus (constellation)| ]] [[Category:Constellations]] [[Category:Northern constellations]] [[Category:Constellations listed by Ptolemy]]

revision.comment: edit per Baja Tom
revision.text:
{{Other uses|Orion (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox constellation | name = Orion | abbreviation = Ori | genitive = Orionis | pronounce = {{IPAc-en|ɒ|ˈ|r|aɪ|.|ən}} | symbolism = [[Orion (mythology)|Orion]], the Hunter | RA = 5 | dec = +5 | family = [[Orion Family|Orion]] | quadrant = NQ1 | areatotal = 594 | arearank = 26th | numbermainstars = 7 | numberbfstars = 81 | numberstarsplanets = 10 | numberbrightstars = 8 | numbernearbystars = 8 | brighteststarname = [[Rigel]] (β Ori) | starmagnitude = 0.12 | neareststarname = [[GJ 3379]] | stardistancely = 17.51 | stardistancepc = 5.37 | numbermessierobjects = 3 | meteorshowers = [[Orionids]]
[[Chi Orionids]] | bordering = [[Gemini (constellation)|Gemini]]
[[Taurus (constellation)|Taurus]]
[[Eridanus (constellation)|Eridanus]]
[[Lepus (constellation)|Lepus]]
[[Monoceros]] | latmax = [[85th parallel north|85]] | latmin = [[75th parallel south|75]] | month = January | notes=[[File:Orion 3008 huge.jpg|center|250px|click on to see large image]] }} '''Orion''' is a prominent [[constellation]] located on the [[celestial equator]] and visible throughout the world. It is one of the most conspicuous and recognizable constellations in the night sky.{{cite web |url=http://www.astro.wisc.edu/~dolan/constellations/constellations/Orion.html |title=Orion |first=Chris |last=Dolan |accessdate=2011-11-28 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/63XCardIx |archivedate=2011-11-28 |deadurl=no}} It was named after [[Orion (mythology)|Orion]], a hunter in [[Greek mythology]]. Its brightest stars are [[Rigel]] (Beta Orionis) and [[Betelgeuse]] (Alpha Orionis), a blue-white and a red [[supergiant]] respectively. Many of the other brighter stars in the constellation are hot, blue supergiant stars. The three stars in the middle of the constellation form an [[asterism (astronomy)|asterism]] known as [[Orion's belt]]. The [[Orion Nebula]] is located south of Orion's belt. ==History and mythology== [[File:Sig07-006.jpg|thumb|250px|Star formation in the constellation Orion as photographed in [[infrared]] by [[NASA]]'s [[Spitzer Space Telescope]].]] The earliest depiction that has been linked to the constellation of Orion is a prehistoric ([[Aurignacian]]) mammoth ivory carving found in a cave in the Ach valley in Germany in 1979. Archaeologists have estimated it to have been fashioned approximately 32,000 to 38,000 years ago.{{cite conference |title=The Anthropoid in the Sky: Does a 32,000 Years Old Ivory Plate Show the Constellation Orion Combined with a Pregnancy Calendar |last1=Rappenglück|first1=Michael |year= 2001 |publisher=Uppsala Astronomical Observatory |booktitle=Symbols, Calendars and Orientations: Legacies of Astronomy in Culture|conference=IXth Annual meeting of the European Society for Astronomy in Culture (SEAC)|pages=51–55}}{{cite web |url=http://www2.astronomicalheritage.net/index.php/show-entity?identity=3&idsubentity=1 |title=The Decorated Plate of the Geißenklösterle, Germany |website=UNESCO: Portal to the Heritage of Astronomy |accessdate=26 February 2014}}{{cite news | first=David | last=Whitehouse | date=January 21, 2003 | title='Oldest star chart' found | publisher=BBC | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/2679675.stm | accessdate=26 February 2014 }} The distinctive pattern of Orion has been recognized in numerous cultures around the world, and many myths have been associated with it. It has also been used as a symbol in the modern world. ===Mediterranean=== ====Ancient Near East==== The [[Babylonian star catalogues]] of the [[Late Bronze Age]] name Orion ''{{lang|sux-Latn|MULSIPA.ZI.AN.NA}}'',The [[determiner (cuneiform)|determiner glyph]] for "constellation" or "star" in these lists is '''MUL''' ({{Script|Xsux|𒀯}}). See [[Babylonian star catalogues]]. "The Heavenly Shepherd" or "True Shepherd of Anu" - Anu being the chief god of the heavenly realms.John H. Rogers, "[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1998JBAA..108....9R Origins of the ancient contellations: I. The Mesopotamian traditions]", ''Journal of the British Astronomical Association'' '''108''' (1998) 9–28 The Babylonian constellation was sacred to [[Papsukkal|Papshukal]] and [[Ninshubur]], both minor gods fulfilling the role of 'messenger to the gods'. Papshukal was closely associated with the figure of a walking [[bird]] on Babylonian boundary stones, and on the star map the figure of the [[Rooster]] was located below and behind the figure of the True Shepherd—both constellations represent the herald of the gods, in his bird and human forms respectively.''Babylonian Star-lore'' by Gavin White, Solaria Pubs, 2008, page 218ff & 170 The stars of Orion were associated with [[Osiris]], the sun-god of rebirth and the afterlife, by the [[ancient Egyptian]]s.The Oxford Guide: Essential Guide to Egyptian Mythology, Edited by Donald B. Redford, p302-307, Berkley, 2003, ISBN 0-425-19096-X{{cite book |last= Mackenzie |first= Donald A. |title= Egyptian Myth and Legend |publisher= Gresham Pub. Co. |year= 1907 |isbn= 0-517-25912-5 |chapter=Triumph of the Sun God | chapterurl=http://www.sacred-texts.com/egy/eml/eml15.htm | pages=167–168}}http://www.coldwaterschools.org/lms/planetarium/myth/orion.html;{{Dead link|date=September 2012}} http://www.constellationsofwords.com/Constellations/Orion.html Orion has also been identified with the [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptian]] [[Pharaoh]] of the [[Fifth Dynasty]] called [[Unas]] who, according to the ''[[Pyramid Texts]]'', became great by eating the flesh of his mortal enemies and then slaying and devouring the gods themselves. This was based on a belief in [[contagious magic]] whereby consuming the flesh of great people would bring inheritance of their power. After devouring the gods and absorbing their spirits and powers, Unas journeys through the day and night sky to become the star Sahu, or Orion. The ''Pyramid Texts'' also show that the dead Pharaoh was identified with the god Osiris, whose form in the stars was often said to be the constellation Orion. The [[Armenians]] identified their legendary patriarch and founder [[Hayk]] with Orion. ''Hayk'' is also the name of the Orion constellation in the Armenian translation of the [[Bible]].[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Gazetteer/Places/Asia/Armenia/_Texts/KURARM/8*.html Vahan Kurkjian, "History of Armenia," Michigan, 1968] The [[Bible]] mentions Orion three times, naming it "Kesil" (כסיל, literally - fool). Though, this name perhaps is etymologically connected with "Kislev", the name for the ninth month of the Hebrew calendar (i.e. November–December), which, in turn, may derive from the Hebrew root K-S-L as in the words "kesel, kisla" (כֵּסֶל, כִּסְלָה, hope, positiveness), i.e. hope for winter rains.): [[Book of Job|Job]] 9:9 ("He is the maker of the Bear and Orion"), [[Book of Job|Job]] 38:31 ("Can you loosen Orion`s belt?"), and [[Book of Amos|Amos]] 5:8 ("He who made the [[Pleiades]] and Orion"). In ancient [[Aram (Biblical region)|Aram]], the constellation was known as ''Nephîlā′'', the ''[[Nephilim]]'' may have been Orion's descendants.''[[Peake's commentary on the Bible]]'', 1962, page 260 section 221f. ====Greco-Roman antiquity==== {{Main|Orion (mythology)}} [[File:Aratea 58v.jpg|thumb|Orion in the 9th century [[Leiden Aratea]].]] Orion's current name derives from [[Greek mythology]], in which Orion was a gigantic, supernaturally strong hunter of ancient times,[http://www.ianridpath.com/startales/orion.htm Star Tales – Orion] born to [[Euryale]], a [[Gorgon]], and [[Poseidon]] ([[Neptune (mythology)|Neptune]]), god of the sea in the Graeco-Roman tradition. One myth recounts [[Gaia (mythology)|Gaia]]'s rage at Orion, who dared to say that he would kill every animal on the planet. The angry goddess tried to dispatch Orion with a [[scorpion]]. This is given as the reason that the constellations of [[Scorpius (constellation)|Scorpius]] and Orion are never in the sky at the same time. However, [[Ophiuchus]], the Serpent Bearer, revived Orion with an [[antidote]]. This is said to be the reason that the constellation of Ophiuchus stands midway between the Scorpion and the Hunter in the sky.{{sfn|Staal|1988|pp=61-62}} The constellation is mentioned in [[Horace]]'s ''[[Ode]]s'' (Ode 3.27.18), [[Homer]]'s ''[[Odyssey]]'' (Book 5, line 283) and ''[[Iliad]]'', and [[Virgil]]'s ''[[Aeneid]]'' (Book 1, line 535) ===Africa=== In [[ancient Egypt]], the constellation of Orion represented [[Osiris]], who, after being killed by his evil brother [[Set (Egyptian religion)|Set]], was revived by his wife [[Isis]] to live immortal among the stars.Mystery of the Sphinx. Documentary 2005. Morningstar Entertainment. ===Middle East=== In medieval [[Muslim astronomy]], Orion was known as ''al-jabbar'', "the giant".{{cite book|last=Metlitzki|first=Dorothee|authorlink=Dorothee Metlitzki|title=The Matter of Araby in Medieval England|date=1977|publisher=Yale University Press|location=United States|isbn=0-300-11410-9|page=79|url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=61OjyWngtdsC&pg=PA79#v=onepage&q&f=false}} Orion's sixth brightest star, [[Saiph]], is named from the Arabic, ''saif al-jabbar'', meaning "sword of the giant".{{citation | first1=James B. | last1=Kaler | work=Stars | title=SAIPH (Kappa Orionis) | publisher=University of Illinois | url=http://stars.astro.illinois.edu/sow/saiph.html | accessdate=2012-01-27 }} ===Asian antiquity=== In [[China]], Orion was one of the [[Twenty-eight mansions|28 lunar mansions]] ''Sieu (Xiu)'' （宿）. It is known as [[Three Stars (Chinese constellation)|''Shen'' （參）]], literally meaning "three", for the stars of Orion's Belt. (See [[Chinese constellations]]) The [[Chinese character]] 參 ([[pinyin]] shēn) originally meant the constellation Orion ({{zh|c=參宿|p=shēnxiù}}); its [[Shang dynasty]] version, over three millennia old, contains at the top a representation of the three stars of Orion's belt atop a man's head (the bottom portion representing the sound of the word was added later).漢語大字典 Hànyǔ Dàzìdiǎn (in Chinese), 1992 (p.163). 湖北辭書出版社和四川辭書出版社 Húbĕi Cishu Chūbǎnshè and Sìchuān Cishu Chūbǎnshè, re-published in traditional character form by 建宏出版社 Jiànhóng Publ. in Taipei, Taiwan; ISBN 957-813-478-9 The [[Rig Veda]] refers to the Orion Constellation as '''Mriga''' (The [[Deer]]).{{cite journal|author=Holay, P. V.|title=Vedic astronomers|journal=Bulletin of the Astronomical Society of India|volume=26|pages=91–106|bibcode=1998BASI...26...91H}} It is said that two bright stars in the front and two bright stars in the rear are ''The hunting dogs'', the one comparatively less bright star in the middle and ahead of two front dogs is ''The hunter'' and three aligned bright stars are in the middle of all four hunting dogs is ''The Deer'' (The Mriga) and three little aligned but less brighter stars is ''The Baby Deer''. The Mriga means Deer, locally known as ''Harnu'' in folk parlance. There are many folk songs narrating the ''Harnu''. The [[Malays (ethnic group)|Malay]] called Orion' Belt ''Bintang Tiga Beradik'' (the "Three Brother Star").{{citation needed|date=September 2012}} ===European folklore=== [[Image:OrionCC.jpg|thumb|220px|The constellation Orion as it can be seen by the naked eye.]] [[Image:Orion constellation with star labels.jpg|thumb|The constellation Orion with the major stars labelled.]] In old [[Hungarian people|Hungarian]] tradition, "Orion" is known as (magic) Archer (''Íjász''), or Reaper (''Kaszás''). In recently rediscovered myths he is called [[Nimrod]] ([[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] "Nimród"), the greatest hunter, father of the twins [[Hunor and Magor|"Hunor" and "Magor"]]). The "π" and "o" stars (on upper right) form together the [[reflex bow]] or the lifted scythe. In other Hungarian traditions, "Orion's belt" is known as "Judge's stick" (''Bírópálca'').Toroczkai-Wigand Ede : Öreg csillagok ("Old stars"), Hungary (1915) reedited with Műszaki Könyvkiadó METRUM (1988). In [[Scandinavia]]n tradition, "Orion's belt" was known as [[Frigg]]'s [[Distaff]] (''Friggerock'') or [[Freyja]]'s distaff.Schön, Ebbe. (2004). ''Asa-Tors hammare, Gudar och jättar i tro och tradition''. Fält & Hässler, Värnamo. p. 228. The [[Finns]] call the Orion's belt and the stars below it as ''Väinämöisen viikate'' ([[Väinämöinen]]'s [[scythe]]).{{cite web|author=Ismo Elo |url=http://www.ursa.fi/yhd/uranus/luennot%202004/perusteet/tahdet.htm |title=Tähdet ja tähdistöt |publisher=Ursa.fi |accessdate=October 16, 2013}} Another name for the asterism of Alnilam, Alnitak and Minkata is ''Väinämöisen vyö''' (Väinämöinen's Belt) and the stars "hanging" from the belt as ''Kalevanmiekka'' ([[Kalevi (mythology)|Kaleva]]'s [[sword]]). In [[Siberia]], the [[Chukchi people]] see Orion as a hunter; an arrow he has shot is represented by Aldebaran (Alpha Tauri), with the same figure as other Western depictions.{{sfn|Staal|1988|p=63}} ===Americas=== The [[Seri people]] of northwestern Mexico call the three stars in the belt of Orion ''Hapj'' (a name denoting a hunter) which consists of three stars: ''Hap'' (mule deer), ''Haamoja'' (pronghorn), and ''Mojet'' (bighorn sheep). ''Hap'' is in the middle and has been shot by the hunter; its blood has dripped onto [[Tiburón Island]].{{cite book |last=Moser |first=Mary B. |coauthors=Stephen A. Marlett |title=Comcáac quih yaza quih hant ihíip hac: Diccionario seri-español-inglés |url=http://lengamer.org/admin/language_folders/seri/user_uploaded_files/links/File/DiccionarioSeri2005.pdf |year=2005 |publisher=Universidad de Sonora and Plaza y Valdés Editores |location=Hermosillo, Sonora and Mexico City|language=Spanish and English}} The same three stars are known in Spain and most of Latin America as "Las tres Marías" (Spanish for "[[The Three Marys]]"). In Puerto Rico, the three stars are known as the "Los Tres Reyes Magos" (Spanish for [[Biblical Magi|The three Wise Men]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/tresreyesmagosenelcieloestanoche-1421862.html |title=Home - El Nuevo Día |publisher=Elnuevodia.com |accessdate=October 16, 2013}} The [[Ojibwa]] (Chippewa) Native Americans call this constellation Kabibona'kan, the Winter Maker, as its presence in the night sky heralds winter.{{citation needed|date=September 2012}} To the [[Lakota people|Lakota]] Native Americans, Tayamnicankhu (Orion’s Belt) is the spine of a bison. The great rectangle of Orion are the bison's ribs; the Pleiades star cluster in nearby Taurus is the bison’s head; and Sirius in Canis Major, known as Tayamnisinte, is its tail. ===Contemporary symbolism=== The imagery of the belt and sword has found its way into popular western culture, for example in the form of the shoulder [[insignia]] of the [[27th Infantry Division (United States)|27th Infantry Division]] of the [[United States Army]] during both World Wars, probably owing to a pun on the name of the division's first commander, Major General [[John F. O'Ryan|John F. ''O'Ryan'']].{{citation needed|date=September 2012}} The defunct film distribution company [[Orion Pictures]] used the constellation as its logo.{{citation needed|date=September 2012}} ====In fiction==== In [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]'s mythology surrounding [[Middle-earth]], Orion is known as ''Menelvagor'', which is [[Sindarin]] for "The Swordsman in the Sky."{{cite web|url=http://www.glyphweb.com/arda/s/swordsmanofthesky.html |title=Encyclopedia of Arda: Swordsman of the Sky |publisher=Glyphweb.com |date=1999-11-27 |accessdate=2012-05-16}} In the movie ''[[Blade Runner]]'', the dying replicant [[Roy Batty]] introspectively delivers his [[tears in rain soliloquy|"Tears in Rain" soliloquy]]: {{quote|I've... seen things you people wouldn't believe... Attack ships on fire off the ''shoulder of Orion''. I watched c-beams glitter in the dark near the Tannhäuser Gate. All those... moments... will be lost in time, like tears... in... rain. Time... to die...}} In the sci-fi comedy ''[[Men In Black]]'', the last words of a dying alien disguised as a human were 'To prevent war, the Galaxy is on Orion's belt'. It was later revealed that 'Orion's belt' referred to the collar of a cat named 'Orion'. In the sci-fi television series ''[[Haven (TV series)|Haven]]'', the Orionid meteor shower is known as the ''Hunter Meteor Shower''. It comes to Haven once every twenty-seven years when the Barn, a space between two worlds, comes to take the mysterious woman away. When the Barn leaves, the Hunter passes safely overhead and [[The Troubles (Haven)|The Troubles]] end, making the town of Haven a haven for the Troubled again. ===Depictions=== In artistic renderings, the surrounding constellations are sometimes related to Orion: he is depicted standing next to the river [[Eridanus (constellation)|Eridanus]] with his two hunting dogs [[Canis Major]] and [[Canis Minor]], fighting [[Taurus (constellation)|Taurus]] He is sometimes depicted hunting [[Lepus (constellation)|Lepus]] the [[hare]]. He also sometimes is depicted to have a lion's hide in his hand. There are alternative ways to visualise Orion. From the [[Southern Hemisphere]], Orion is oriented south-upward, and the belt and sword are sometimes called the saucepan or pot in [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]]. Orion's Belt is called ''Drie Konings'' (Three Kings) or the ''Drie Susters'' (Three Sisters) by [[Afrikaans language|Afrikaans]] speakers in [[South Africa]][http://www.psychohistorian.org/astronomy/ethnoastronomy/three_kings_cape_clouds.php Three Kings and the Cape Clouds at psychohistorian.org] and are referred to as ''les Trois Rois'' (the Three Kings) in [[Alphonse Daudet|Daudet]]'s ''Lettres de Mon Moulin'' (1866). The appellation ''Driekoningen'' (the Three Kings) is also often found in 17th- and 18th-century Dutch star charts and seaman's guides. The same three stars are known in [[Spain]], [[Latin America]], and the [[Philippines]] as "Las Tres Marías" (The Three Marys), and as "Los Tres Reyes Magos" (The three Wise Men) in Puerto Rico. Even traditional depictions of Orion have varied greatly. [[Cicero]] drew Orion in a similar fashion to the modern depiction. The Hunter held an unidentified animal skin aloft in his right hand; his hand was represented by [[Omicron2 Orionis|Omicron2 Orionis]] and the skin was represented by the 5 stars designated [[Pi Orionis]]. Kappa and Beta Orionis represented his left and right knees, while Eta and Lambda Leporis were his left and right feet, respectively. As in the modern depiction, Delta, Epsilon, and Zeta represented his belt. His left shoulder was represented by Alpha Orionis, and Mu Orionis made up his left arm. Lambda Orionis was his head and Gamma, his right shoulder. The depiction of [[Hyginus]] was similar to that of Cicero, though the two differed in a few important areas. Cicero's animal skin became Hyginus's shield (Omicron and Pi Orionis), and instead of an arm marked out by Mu Orionis, he holds a club (Chi Orionis). His right leg is represented by Theta Orionis and his left leg is represented by Lambda, Mu, and Epsilon Leporis. Further Western European and Arabic depictions have followed these two models.{{sfn|Staal|1988|p=63}} ==Characteristics== Orion is bordered by Taurus to the northwest, Eridanus to the southwest, Lepus to the south, [[Monoceros]] to the east, and Gemini to the northeast. Covering 594 square degrees, Orion ranks twenty-sixth of the 88 constellations in size. The constellation boundaries, as set by [[Eugène Joseph Delporte|Eugène Delporte]] in 1930, are defined by a polygon of 26 sides. In the [[equatorial coordinate system]], the [[right ascension]] coordinates of these borders lie between {{RA|04|43.3}} and {{RA|06|25.5}}, while the [[declination]] coordinates are between {{dec|22.87}} and {{dec|−10.97}}.{{cite journal | title=Orion, Constellation Boundary | work=The Constellations | publisher=International Astronomical Union | url=http://www.iau.org/public/constellations/#ori | accessdate=22 March 2013}} The constellation's three-letter abbreviation, as adopted by the [[International Astronomical Union]] in 1922, is "Ori".{{cite journal | last=Russell | first=Henry Norris | title=The New International Symbols for the Constellations | journal=Popular Astronomy | volume=30 | pages=469–71 |bibcode=1922PA.....30..469R | year=1922}} Orion is most visible in the evening sky from January to March,{{cite book|author=Ellyard, David; Tirion, Wil |year=2008 |title=The Southern Sky Guide|edition = 3rd|origyear=1993|page=4|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=5Gn0ivM4EK0C&pg=PA4 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Port Melbourne, Victoria |isbn= 978-0-521-71405-1}} winter in the Northern Hemisphere, and summer in the Southern Hemisphere. In the tropics (less than about 8° from the equator), the constellation transits at the zenith. In the period May–July (summer in the Northern Hemisphere, winter in the Southern Hemisphere), Orion is in the daytime sky and thus not visible at most latitudes. However, for much of [[Antarctica]] in the Southern Hemisphere's winter months, the Sun is below the [[horizon]] even at midday. Stars (and thus Orion) are then visible at twilight for a few hours around local noon, low in the North. At the same time of day at the South Pole itself ([[Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station]]), Rigel is only 8° above the horizon, and the Belt sweeps just along it. In the Southern Hemisphere's summer months, when Orion is normally visible in the night sky, the constellation is actually not visible in Antarctica because the sun does not set at that time of year south of the Antarctic Circle.[http://www.dibonsmith.com/downunder.htm A Beginner's Guide to the Heavens in the Southern Hemisphere][http://skymaps.com/downloads.html The Evening Sky Map Southern Hemisphere Edition] In countries close to the equator (e.g. Kenya, Indonesia, Colombia, Ecuador), Orion appears overhead in December around midnight and in the February evening sky. ==Navigational aid== [[File:Orion-guide dark.svg|thumb|220px|left|Using Orion to find stars in neighbor constellations.]] Orion is very useful as an aid to locating other stars. By extending the line of the Belt southeastward, [[Sirius]] (α [[Canis Major|CMa]]) can be found; northwestward, [[Aldebaran]] (α [[Taurus (constellation)|Tau]]). A line eastward across the two shoulders indicates the direction of [[Procyon]] (α [[Canis Minor|CMi]]). A line from [[Rigel]] through [[Betelgeuse]] points to [[Castor (star)|Castor]] and [[Pollux (star)|Pollux]] (α [[Gemini (constellation)|Gem]] and β Gem). Additionally, Rigel is part of the [[Winter Hexagon|Winter Circle]]. Sirius and [[Procyon]], which may be located from Orion by following imaginary lines (see map), also are points in both the [[Winter Triangle]] and the Circle.[http://www.donnayoung.org/science/stars/orion.htm Orion Constellation]{{sfn|Staal|1988|p=61}} ==Major features== {{See also|List of stars in Orion}} [[File:Sidney Hall - Urania's Mirror - Orion (best currently available version - 2014).jpg|thumb|210px|Orion as depicted in ''[[Urania's Mirror]]'', a set of constellation cards published in London c.1825.]] Orion's seven brightest stars form a distinctive hourglass-shaped [[asterism (astronomy)|asterism]], or pattern, in the night sky. Four stars—Rigel, Betelgeuse, Bellatrix and Saiph—form a large roughly rectangular shape, in the centre of which lie the three stars of [[Orion's Belt]]—[[Alnitak]], [[Alnilam]] and [[Mintaka]]. Descending from the 'belt' is a smaller line of three stars (the middle of which is in fact not a star but the [[Orion Nebula]]), known as the hunter's 'sword'. Many of the stars are luminous hot blue supergiants, with the stars of the belt and sword forming the [[Orion OB1 Association]]. Standing out by its red hue, Betelgeuse may nevertheless be a runaway member of the same group. ===Stars=== *'''[[Betelgeuse]]''', alternatively by its [[Bayer designation]] Alpha Orionis, is a massive [[M-type star|M-type]] red [[supergiant]] star nearing the end of its life. When it explodes it will even be visible during the day. It is the second brightest star in Orion, and is a [[semiregular variable]] star.{{cite web |url=http://www.aavso.org/vstar/vsots/1200.shtml |title=Variable Star of the Month, Alpha Ori |accessdate=2009-02-26 |work=Variable Star of the Season |publisher=[[American Association of Variable Star Observers]] |year=2000 }} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} It serves as the "right shoulder" of the hunter it represents (assuming that he is facing the observer), and is the eighth brightest star in the night sky.{{cite web |url=http://www.astro.wisc.edu/~dolan/constellations/hr/2061.html |title=Betelgeuse |accessdate=2009-02-26 |work=Chris Dolan's Constellations |publisher=[[University of Wisconsin]] |year=2009 }} *'''[[Rigel]]''', which is also known as Beta Orionis, is a [[B-type star|B-type]] blue supergiant that is the sixth brightest star in the night sky. Similar to Betelgeuse, Rigel is [[nuclear fusion|fusing]] [[heavy element]]s in its core and will pass its [[supergiant]] stage soon (on an astronomical timescale), either collapsing in the case of a [[supernova]] or shedding its outer layers and turning into a [[white dwarf]]. It serves as the left foot of Orion, the hunter.{{cite web |url=http://www.astro.uiuc.edu/~jkaler/sow/rigel.html |title=Rigel |accessdate=2009-02-26 |work=Jim Kaler's Stars |publisher=[[University of Illinois]], [[Urbana, Illinois|Urbana]]-[[Champaign, Illinois|Champaign]] [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign|Campus]] |year=2009 }}{{Dead link|date=September 2012}} *'''[[Bellatrix]]''' was designated Gamma Orionis by [[Johann Bayer]], but is known colloquially as the "Amazon Star". It is the twenty-seventh brightest star in the night sky.{{cite web |url=http://www.astro.wisc.edu/~dolan/constellations/hr/1790.html |title=Bellatrix |accessdate=2009-02-26 |work=Chris Dolan's Constellations |publisher=[[University of Wisconsin]] |year=2009 }} Bellatrix is considered a [[B-type star|B-type]] blue giant, though it is too small to explode in a [[supernova]]. Bellatrix's luminosity is derived from its high temperature rather than its radius,{{cite web |url=http://www.astro.uiuc.edu/~jkaler/sow/bellatrix.html |title=Bellatrix |accessdate=2009-02-26 |work=Jim Kaler's Stars |publisher=[[University of Illinois]], [[Urbana, Illinois|Urbana]]-[[Champaign, Illinois|Champaign]] [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign|Campus]] |year=2009 }}{{Dead link|date=September 2012}} a factor that defines Betelgeuse. Bellatrix serves as Orion's left shoulder. *'''[[Delta Orionis|Mintaka]]''' garnered the name Delta Orionis from Bayer, even though it is the faintest of the three stars in [[Orion's Belt]]. Its name means "the Giant's belt".{{sfn|Staal|1988|p=61}} It is a [[multiple star system]], composed of a large [[B-type star|B-type]] blue giant and a more massive [[O-type star|O-type]] white star. The Mintaka system constitutes an [[eclipsing binary]] variable star, where the eclipse of one star over the other creates a dip in brightness. Mintaka is the westernmost of the three stars of Orion's Belt,{{cite web |url=http://stars.astro.illinois.edu/sow/mintaka.html |title=Mintaka |accessdate=2011-11-28 |work=Jim Kaler's Stars |publisher=[[University of Illinois]], [[Urbana, Illinois|Urbana]]-[[Champaign, Illinois|Champaign]] [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign|Campus]] |year=2009 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/63XCA2Co1 |archivedate=2011-11-28 |deadurl=no}} as well as the northernmost.{{sfn|Staal|1988|p=61}} [[File:Orion constelation PP3 map PL.jpg|thumb|right|Orion Constellation Map]] *'''[[Epsilon Orionis|Alnilam]]''' is designated Epsilon Orionis, a consequence of Bayer's wish to name the three stars in Orion's Belt (from north to south) in alphabetical order. Also called Al Nathin, Alnilam is named for the Arabic phrase meaning "string of pearls".{{sfn|Staal|1988|p=61}} Alnilam is a [[B-type star|B-type]] blue supergiant; despite being nearly twice as far from the Sun as [[Delta Orionis|Mintaka]] and [[Zeta Orionis|Alnitak]], the other two belt stars, its luminosity makes it nearly equal in magnitude. Alnilam is losing mass quickly, a consequence of its size; it is approximately four million years old.{{cite web |url=http://stars.astro.illinois.edu/sow/alnilam.html |title=Alnilam |accessdate=2011-11-28 |work=Jim Kaler's Stars |publisher=[[University of Illinois]], [[Urbana, Illinois|Urbana]]-[[Champaign, Illinois|Champaign]] [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign|Campus]] |year=2009 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/63XBTECPT |archivedate=2011-11-28 |deadurl=no}} *'''[[Alnitak]]''', meaning "the girdle",{{sfn|Staal|1988|p=61}} was designated Zeta Orionis by Bayer, and is the easternmost star in Orion's Belt. It is a [[Multiple star|triple star]] some 800 light years distant, with the primary star being a hot [[blue supergiant]] and the brightest [[O star|class O]] [[star]] in the night sky. *'''[[Saiph]]''' was designated Kappa Orionis by Bayer, and serves as Orion's right foot. It is of a similar distance and size to Rigel, but appears much fainter, as its hot surface temperature (46,000 °F or 26,000 °C) causes it to emit most of its light in the [[ultraviolet]] region of the spectrum. Of the lesser stars, [[Hatsya]] (or Iota Orionis) forms the tip of Orion's sword, whilst [[Meissa]] (or Lambda Orionis) forms Orion's head. Iota Orionis is also called Nair al-Saif, Arabic for "the brightest in the sword".{{sfn|Staal|1988|p=61}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! | Proper
Name || Solar Radii|| Apparent
Magnitude || ~Distance
(L Yrs) |- | [[Alpha Orionis|  Betelgeuse]] ||     667 ||       0.43 ||    643 |- | [[Beta Orionis|  Rigel]] ||    78 ||       0.18 ||    772 |- | [[Gamma Orionis|  Bellatrix]] ||     7.0 ||       1.62 ||    243 |- | [[Delta Orionis|  Mintaka]] ||     ? ||       2.23 (3.2/3.3) / 6.85 / 14.0 ||    900 |- | [[Epsilon Orionis|  Alnilam]] ||     26 ||       1.68 ||    1359 |- | [[Zeta Orionis|  Alnitak]] ||     20 ||       1.70/~4/4.21 ||    800 |- | [[Kappa Orionis|  Saiph]] ||     11 ||       2.06 ||    724 |} ===Belt=== {{main|Orion's Belt}} {{multiple image |align=right |direction=vertical |width=200 |image1=Cintura di Orione binocolo.png |caption1=Orion's Belt |image2=Orion Belt.jpg |caption2=Closeup Image of Orion's Belt}} '''Orion's Belt''' or '''The Belt of Orion''' is an [[Asterism (astronomy)|asterism]] within the constellation. It consists of the three bright stars [[Zeta Orionis|Zeta]] (Alnitak), [[Epsilon Orionis|Epsilon]] (Alnilam), and [[Delta Orionis|Delta]] (Mintaka). Alnitak is around 800 light years away from earth and is 100,000 times more luminous than the [[Sun]]; much of its radiation is in the ultraviolet range, which the human eye cannot see.{{cite web|url=http://stars.astro.illinois.edu/sow/alnitak.html |title=Alnitak |publisher=Stars.astro.illinois.edu |accessdate=2012-05-16}} Alnilam is approximately 1340 light years away from Earth, shines with magnitude 1.70, and with ultraviolet light is 375,000 times more luminous than the Sun. Mintaka is 915 light years away and shines with magnitude 2.21. It is 90,000 times more luminous than the Sun and is a double star: the two orbit each other every 5.73 days. Looking for Orion's Belt in the night sky is the easiest way to locate the constellation. In the Northern Hemisphere, Orion's Belt is best visible in the night sky during the month of January around 9:00 pm, when it is approximately around the local [[meridian (astronomy)|meridian]]. Just southwest of Alnitak lies [[Sigma Orionis]], a multiple star system composed of five stars that have a combined apparent magnitude of 3.7 and lying 1150 light years distant. Southwest of Mintaka lies the quadruple star [[Eta Orionis]]. ===Head=== Three stars compose a small triangle that marks the head. The apex is marked by [[Meissa]] (Lambda Orionis), a hot blue giant of spectral type O8 III and apparent magnitude 3.54, which lies some 1100 light years distant. Phi-1 and Phi-2 Orionis make up the base. Also nearby is the very young star [[FU Orionis]]. ===North Arrow=== Together the 'Alnitak, Alnilam, & Mintaka', the 'M42, M43' at the lower end form the tail of an arrow while 'Alnilam' form the head of the arrow. All together form an arrow that always points 'NORTH'. Therefore, it is used as navigational guide at night especially in the Sahara desert where there are not many natural signs. ===Club=== Stretching north from Betelgeuse are the stars that make up Orion's club. [[Mu Orionis]] marks the elbow, [[Nu Orionis|Nu]] and [[Xi Orionis|Xi]] mark the handle of the club, and [[Chi1 Orionis|Chi1]] and [[Chi2 Orionis|Chi2]] mark the end of the club. Just east of Chi1 is the Mira-type variable red giant [[U Orionis]]. ===Shield=== West from Bellatrix lie six stars all designated [[Pi Orionis]] ([[Pi1 Orionis|π1 Ori]], [[Pi2 Orionis|π2 Ori]], [[Pi3 Orionis|π3 Ori]], [[Pi4 Orionis|π4 Ori]], [[Pi5 Orionis|π5 Ori]] and [[Pi6 Orionis|π6 Ori]]) which make up Orion's shield. ===Meteor showers=== Around 20 October each year the [[Orionids|Orionid meteor shower]] (Orionids) reaches its peak. Coming from the border with the constellation Gemini as many as 20 meteors per hour can be seen. The shower's parent body is [[Halley's Comet]].{{cite journal |journal = Sky & Telescope |date = September 2012 |last = Jenniskens |first = Peter |page = 22 |title = Mapping Meteoroid Orbits: New Meteor Showers Discovered}} ===Deep-sky objects=== [[File:Orion Head to Toe.jpg|thumb|This view brings out many fainter features, such as [[Barnard's Loop|Barnards loop]].]] Hanging from Orion's belt is his sword, consisting of the multiple stars θ1 and θ2 Orionis, called the [[Trapezium (astronomy)|Trapezium]] and the [[Orion Nebula]] (M42). This is a spectacular object that can be clearly identified with the naked eye as something other than a star. Using binoculars, its clouds of nascent stars, luminous gas, and dust can be observed. The Trapezium cluster has many newborn stars, including several [[brown dwarfs]], all of which are at an approximate distance of 1,500 light-years. Named for the four bright stars that form a [[trapezoid]], it is largely illuminated by the brightest stars, which are only a few hundred thousand years old. Observations by the [[Chandra X-ray Observatory]] show both the extreme temperatures of the main stars—up to 60,000 [[Kelvin]]—and the [[star formation|star forming regions]] still extant in the surrounding nebula.{{cite book |title = 300 Astronomical Objects: A Visual Reference to the Universe |last1=Wilkins |first1=Jamie |last2=Dunn |first2 = Robert |publisher = Firefly Books |year = 2006 |accessdate = 29 April 2012 |edition = 1st |location=Buffalo, New York |isbn = 978-1-55407-175-3}} [[Messier 78|M78]] (NGC 2068) is a nebula in Orion. With an overall magnitude of 8.0, it is significantly dimmer than the Great Orion Nebula that lies to its south; however, it is at approximately the same distance, at 1600 light-years from Earth. It can easily be mistaken for a [[comet]] in the eyepiece of a telescope. M78 is associated with the [[variable star]] [[V351 Orionis]], whose magnitude changes are visible in very short periods of time.{{sfn|Levy|2005|pp=99–100}} Another fairly bright nebula in Orion is [[NGC 1999]], also close to the Great Orion Nebula. It has an integrated magnitude of 10.5 and is 1500 light-years from Earth. The variable star [[V380 Orionis]] is embedded in NGC 1999.{{sfn|Levy|2005|p=107}} Another famous [[nebula]] is [[Index Catalogue|IC]] 434, the [[Horsehead Nebula]], near ζ Orionis. It contains a dark dust cloud whose shape gives the nebula its name. Besides these nebulae, surveying Orion with a small [[telescope]] will reveal a wealth of interesting deep-sky objects, including [[Messier 43|M43]], [[Messier 78|M78]], as well as multiple stars including [[Iota Orionis]] and [[Sigma Orionis]]. A larger telescope may reveal objects such as [[Barnard's Loop]] and the [[Flame Nebula]] (NGC 2024), as well as fainter and tighter multiple stars and nebulae. All of these nebulae are part of the larger [[Orion Molecular Cloud Complex]], which is located approximately 1,500 light-years away and is hundreds of light-years across. It is one of the most intense regions of stellar formation visible in our galaxy. ==Future== Orion is located on the celestial equator, but it will not always be so located due to the effects of [[precession]] of the Earth's axis. Orion lies well south of the [[ecliptic]], and it only happens to lie on the celestial equator because the point on the ecliptic that corresponds to the June solstice is close to the border of [[Gemini (constellation)|Gemini]] and [[Taurus (constellation)|Taurus]], to the north of Orion. Precession will eventually carry Orion further south, and by AD 14000 Orion will be far enough south that it will become invisible from the latitude of Great Britain.{{cite web|url=http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/moonkmft/Articles/Precession.html |title=Precession |publisher=Myweb.tiscali.co.uk |accessdate=2012-05-16}} Further in the future, Orion's stars will gradually move away from the constellation due to [[proper motion]]. However, Orion's brightest stars all lie at a large distance from the Earth on an astronomical scale—much farther away than [[Sirius]], for example. Orion will still be recognizable long after most of the other constellations—composed of relatively nearby stars—have distorted into new configurations, with the exception of a few of its stars eventually exploding as [[supernova]]e, for example [[Betelgeuse]], which is predicted to explode sometime in the next million years.{{cite web|last=Wilkins|first=Alasdair|title=Earth may soon have a second sun|url=http://io9.com/5738542/earth-may-soon-have-a-second-sun|work=io9|publisher=Space Porn}} ==See also== * [[EURion constellation]] * [[Orvandil]] * [[Urania]] * [[Nebulae in fiction#Orion Nebula|Orion Nebula in fiction]] * [[Orion correlation theory]] * ''[[Hubble 3D]]'' (2010), an IMAX film with an elaborate CGI "fly-through" of the Orion Nebula ==References== ;Explanatory notes {{Reflist|group="note"}} ;Citations {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ;Bibliography * {{cite book | first = David H. | last = Levy | title = Deep Sky Objects | year = 2005 | publisher = Prometheus Books | isbn = 1-59102-361-0 | ref = harv }} * Ian Ridpath and Wil Tirion (2007). ''Stars and Planets Guide'', Collins, London. ISBN 978-0-00-725120-9. Princeton Universitl Press, Princeton. ISBN 978-0-691-13556-4. * {{citation | last = Staal | first = Julius D.W. | title = The New Patterns in the Sky | publisher = McDonald and Woodward Publishing Company | year = 1988 | isbn = 0-939923-04-1 }} ==External links== {{Commons|Orion}} *[http://www.allthesky.com/constellations/orion/ The Deep Photographic Guide to the Constellations: Orion] *[http://museumvictoria.com.au/DiscoveryCentre/Infosheets/Planets/Sky-Tour-for-Binoculars---Orion/ Melbourne Planetarium: Orion Sky Tour] *[http://old.orionsarm.com/galactography/views_of_Orion.html Views of Orion from other places in our Galaxy] *[http://160.114.99.91/astrojan/orion.htm The clickable Orion] *[http://www.ianridpath.com/startales/orion.htm Star Tales – Orion] *[http://blog.deepskycolors.com/archive/2010/10/22/orion-from-Head-to-Toes.html Deep Widefield image of Orion] *[http://www.constellationsofwords.com/Constellations/Orion.html Constellations of Words. Orion] *[http://apod.nasa.gov/apod/ap101023.html APOD - Orion: Head to Toe] *[http://www.constellation-guide.com/constellation-list/orion-constellation/ Orion Constellation at Constellation Guide] *[http://www.universetoday.com/100383/beautiful-astrophoto-zoom-into-orion/ Beautiful Astrophoto: Zoom Into Orion] {{Stars of Orion}} {{navconstel}} {{Sky|05|30|00|+|00|00|00|10}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Orion (Constellation)}} [[Category:Orion (constellation)| ]] [[Category:Constellations]] [[Category:Equatorial constellations]] [[Category:Constellations listed by Ptolemy]] {{Link FA|ar}}

Removed reference to "getting your bearings", as the cited reference gave no evidence for this etymology. A search of dictionaries reveals no link.
